introduction.p: So far most of your work in mathematics has been done using the set of real numbers. We often represent the real numbers by a number line, because they can be matched up one-for-one with the points on the line. Every real number is either rational or irrational, and can be expressed as a decimal number, although irrational numbers are non-repeating, non-terminating decimals. However, the real numbers are actually a subset of a larger set of numbers called the complex numbers.

sidebyside.p: You may have first encountered complex numbers as solutions of certain quadratic equations. For example, the graph of f(x)=x^2-2x+2 has no x-intercepts (as shown at right), because the equation ~~x^2-2x+2-0~~ has no real-valued solutions.

subsection.title: Imaginary Numbers
subsection.p: Although square roots of negative numbers such as \sqrt{-4} are not real numbers, they occur often in mathematics and its applications. Mathematicians began working with square roots of negative numbers in the sixteenth century, in their attempts to solve quadratic and cubic equations. Ren√© Descartes gave them the name imaginary numbers, which reflected the mistrust with which mathematicians regarded them at the time. Today, however, such numbers are well understood and used routinely by scientists and engineers.
We begin by defining a new number, called i, whose square is -1.

assemblage.title: Imaginary Unit
assemblage.p: We define the imaginary unit, i, by \blert{i^2=-1}~~~~~~\text{or}~~~~~~\blert{i=\sqrt{-1}}

subsection.p: The letter i used in this way is not a variable, it is the name of a specific number, and hence is a constant. The square root of any negative number can be written as the product of a real number and i. For example, \sqrt{-4} \amp = \sqrt{-1 \cdot 4} \amp = \sqrt{-1} \sqrt{4} = i \cdot 2 or \sqrt{-4} = 2i. Any number that is the product of i and a real number is called an imaginary number.

assemblage.title: Imaginary Numbers
assemblage.p: For any real number a \gt 0, \blert{\sqrt{-a} = \sqrt{-1}\sqrt{a} = i\sqrt{a}}

subsection.p: Examples of imaginary numbers are 3i,~ \dfrac{7}{8}i,~ -38i, and i\sqrt{5}.
Just as each positive number has two real-valued square roots, every negative number has two imaginary square roots. For example, the two square roots of -9 are 3i and -3i.

subsection.title: Complex Numbers
subsection.p: Consider the quadratic equation x^2 - 2x + 5 = 0 Using the quadratic formula to solve the equation, we find x=\dfrac{-(-2) \pm \sqrt{(-2)^2-4(1)(5)}}{2} = \dfrac{2 \pm \sqrt{-16}}{2} If we now replace \sqrt{-16} by 4i, we have x = \dfrac{2 \pm 4i}{2} = 1 \pm 2i The two solutions are 1 + 2i and 1 - 2i. These are examples of complex numbers.

assemblage.title: Complex Numbers

subsection.p: Examples of complex numbers are 3-5i,~ 2+\sqrt{7}i,~ \dfrac{4-i}{3},~ 6i,~~\text{and} ~~ -9 In a complex number a+bi, a is called the real partreal part, and b is called the imaginary partimaginary part. All real numbers are also complex numbers (with imaginary part equal to zero). A complex number whose real part equals 0 is called a pure imaginary numberpure imaginary numberimaginary number.
The real and imaginary parts of a complex number cannot be combined. Thus, two complex numbers z_1 and z_2 are equal if and only if their real parts are equal and their imaginary parts are equal.

assemblage.title: Equality of Complex Numbers
assemblage.p: Two complex numbers z_1 = a + bi and z_2 = c + di are equal if and only if a = c ~~ \text{and} ~~ c = d

statement.p: The solutions of the equation x^2-2x+2=0 are \dfrac{2 \pm \sqrt{-4}}{2}. Write these solutions as complex numbers, and simplify.

solution.p: Because \sqrt{-4} = \sqrt{-1}\sqrt{4} = 2i, we have \dfrac{2 \pm \sqrt{-4}}{2} = \dfrac{2 \pm 2i}{2}, or 1 \pm i. The solutions are 1+i and 1-i.

statement.p: Use extraction of roots to solve (2x+1)^2 + 9 = 0. Write your answers as complex numbers.

subsection.title: Arithmetic of Complex Numbers
subsection.p: We add and subtract complex numbers by combining their real and imaginary parts separately. For example, (4+5i)+(2-3i) \amp = (4+2) + (5-3)i \amp = 6+2i The algebraic form of this rule can be stated as follows.

assemblage.title: Sum and Difference of Complex Numbers

statement.p: Subtract: (8-6i)-(5+2i).

solution.p: Combine the real and imaginary parts. (8-6i)-(5+2i)\amp= (8-5)+(-6-2)i \amp=3+(-8)i = 3-8i

statement.p: Subtract: (-3+2i)-(-3-2i)

subsection.title: Products of Complex Numbers
subsection.p: To find the product of two imaginary numbers, we use the fact that i^2=-1. For example, (3i)(4i)\amp= 3 \cdot 4i^2 \amp=12(-1)=-12
To find the product of two complex numbers, we use the distributive law, as if the numbers were binomials.

statement.p: Multiply (2+3i)(3-5i).

solution.p: We multiply each term of the first complex number by each term of the second one. (2+3i)(3-5i)=6-10i+9i-15i^2 Because i^2=-1, the last term, -15i^2, can be replaced by -15(-1), or 15, to obtain 6-10i+9i+15 Finally, we combine the real parts and imaginary parts to obtain (6+15)+(-10i+9i) = 21-i

statement.p: Multiply (-3+2i)(-3-2i).

subsection.p: In the Homework Probems, you will verify that the following rule holds.

assemblage.title: Product of Complex Numbers
assemblage.p: The product of two complex numbers z_1=a+bi and z_2=c+di is \blert{z_1z_2=(a+bi)(c+di) = (ac-bd)+(ad+bc)i}

warning.p: One property of real numbers that is not true of complex numbers is \sqrt{ab} = \sqrt{a}\sqrt{b}. This identity fails when a and b are both negative. For example, if a=b=-2, we have \sqrt{ab} = \sqrt{(-2)(-2)}=\sqrt{4}=2 but \sqrt{a} \cdot \sqrt{b} \amp= \sqrt{(-2)} \cdot \sqrt{(-2)} \amp =\sqrt{(-1 \cdot 2)} \cdot \sqrt{(-1 \cdot 2)} \amp =i\sqrt{2} \cdot i\sqrt{2} = i^2(\sqrt{2})^2 = -2 so \sqrt{ab} \not= \sqrt{a}\sqrt{b}. We can avoid possible errors by writing square roots of negative numbers as imaginary numbers before attempting any calculations.

subsection.title: Quotients of Complex Numbers
subsection.p: To find the quotient of two complex numbers, we use the technique of rationalizing the denominator. First consider division by a pure imaginary number.

statement.p: Divide \dfrac{3+4i}{2i}.
Divide \dfrac{8+9i}{3i}.

subsection.p: Perhaps you recall that to rationalize a binomial denominator, we multiply by its conjugate. For example, to rationalize the denominator of \dfrac{5}{2+\sqrt{3}}, we multiply numerator and denominator by 2-\sqrt{3}. A similar technique works for dividing complex numbers. We first define the conjugatecomplex conjugateconjugatecomplex conjugate of a complex number.

note.p: The conjugate of a complex number has several useful properties. In particular, the product of a nonzero complex number and its conjugate is always a positive real number. z \bar{z} = (a+bi)(a-bi) = a^2 - b^2i^2 = a^2 - b^2(-1)=a^2+b^2

subsection.p: To illustrate, we calculate the quotient \dfrac{5}{2+3i}. We multiply numerator and denominator by the complex conjugate of the denominator, 2-3i, to obtain \dfrac{5}{2+3i} \cdot \dfrac{2-3i}{2-3i} The denominator is then a real number, because (2+3i)(2-3i) = 4-6i+6i-9i^2 = 4+9 = 13 and the quotient is \dfrac{5}{2+3i} \cdot \dfrac{2-3i}{2-3i}=\dfrac{10-15i}{13} = \dfrac{10}{13} - \dfrac{15}{13}i

statement.p: Divide \dfrac{2+3i}{4-2i}.
Write the quotient \dfrac{4-2i}{1+i} in the form a+bi.

subsection.p: In the Homework Problems you will verify the rule for dividing complex numbers.

assemblage.title: Quotient of Complex Numbers
assemblage.p: The quotient of two complex numbers z_1=a+bi and z_2=c+di is \blert{\dfrac{z_1}{z_2} = \dfrac{a+bi}{c+di} = \dfrac{a+bi}{c+di} \cdot \dfrac{c-di}{c-di} = \dfrac{ac+bd}{c^2+d^2} + \dfrac{bc-ad}{c^2+d^2}i}

subsection.title: Graphing Complex Numbers
subsection.p: Real numbers can be plotted on a number line, but to graph a complex number we use a plane, called the complex plane. In the complex plane, the real numbers lie on the horizontal or real axis, and pure imaginary numbers lie on the vertical or imaginary axis. To plot a complex number a+bi we move a units from the origin in the horizontal direction and b units in the vertical direction.

statement.p: Plot the numbers z=2+3i and \bar{z}=2-3i in the complex plane.

sidebyside.p: To plot z=2+3i, we move from the origin 2 units to the right and 3 units up. To plot \bar{z}=2-3i we move from the origin 2 units to the right and 3 units down. The numbers 2+3i and 2-3i are plotted in the figure at right.

statement.p: Plot z=-3+5i and its conjugate in the complex plane.

warning.p: You are used to plotting ordered pairs (x,y) in the Cartesian plane, so that one point represents two real numbers, given by its coordinates. However, in the complex plane one point represents a single complex number z=a+bi, and the coordinates of the point are the real and imaginary parts of z. For example, the point (2,-6) in the real plane represents the pair of real numbers x=2 and y=-6, but the point (2,-6) in the complex plane represents the complex number z=2-6i.

subsection.p: The modulusmoduluscomplex numberlengthcomplex numberlengthmodulus, or length, of a complex number is its distance from the origin in the complex plane. The modulus of a complex number is analogous to the absolute value of a real number, and is denoted by \abs{z}. If z=a+bi, we can use the Pythagorean theorem to compute its modulus.

assemblage.title: Modulus of a Complex Number
assemblage.p: The modulus of a complex number z=a+bi is given by \blert{\abs{z}=\sqrt{a^2+b^2}}

subsection.p: For example, the modulus of z=2+3i is \abs{z}=\sqrt{2^2+3^2}=\sqrt{13}

statement.p: Plot all points in the complex plane that satisfy the equation \abs{z}=4.

sidebyside.p: The points that satisfy \abs{z}=4 all lie at a distance of 4 units from the origin. In other words, they lie on a circle of radius 4 centered at the origin, as shown at right.

statement.p: Write an equation for the circle of radius 1 centered at the origin in the complex plane.

subsection.p: We can think of the graph of a complex number z=a+bi as the vector (or arrow) that starts at the origin and ends at the point (a,b) in the complex plane, as shown in figure (a).

Then the sum of two complex numbers corresponds to the sum of the two vectors representing them. Figure (b) illustrates the sum of two complex numbers, z_1 and z_2, by vector addition using the parallelogram law: we form a parallelogram with the vectors z_1 and z_2 and as adjacent sides. Their sum is the vector that forms the diagonal of the parallelogram, starting at the origin.

statement.p: Illustrate the sum of z_1=5-i and z_2=-7+4i by vector addition.

sidebyside.p: Draw a vector starting at the origin and ending at the point (5,-1) in the complex plane to represent z_1, and another vector ending at (-7,4) to represent z_2. Now sketch the opposite sides of a parallelogram, and draw the diagonal starting at the origin, as shown at right.

solution.p: This vector represents the sum z_1+z_2. You can check that the vector ends at the point z_1+z_2=(5-7)+(-1+4)i=-2+3i

subsection.title: Zeros of Polynomials
subsection.p: A polynomial with real-number coefficients may or may not have real-valued zeros. For example, the polynomial x^4+4 has no real-valued zeros. But a polynomial always has a zero if we allow complex numbers as inputs. Because we can add, subtract, and multiply any two complex numbers, we can evaluate a polynomial function at a complex number. Thus, we can extend the domain of any polynomial to include all complex numbers.

statement.p: Evaluate the polynomial f(x)=x^2-2x+2 for x=1+i, and simplify.

solution.p: We substitute x=1+i, to find f(1+i) \amp =(1+i)^2 - 2(1+i) +2 \amp = 1^2+2i+i^2-2-2i+2 \amp = 1+2i+(-1)-2-2i+2 Thus, f(1+i)=0, so 1+i is a zero of the polynomial.

statement.p: If f(x)=x^2-6x+13, evaluate f(3+2i).

assemblage.title: Complex Zeros of a Quadratic Polynomial
assemblage.p: If z=a+bi,~b \not= 0, is a complex zero of a quadratic polynomial p(x) with real coefficients and lead coefficient 1, then \bar{z}=a-bi is the other zero, and \blert{p(x)=(x-z)(x-\bar{z})=x^2 - (z+\bar{z})x+z\bar{z}}

ol.li: Let z=7-5i. Compute (z+\bar{z}) and z\bar{z}.
Find a quadratic polynomial with one zero being z=7-5i.
The conjugate of z=7-5i is \bar{z}=7+5i, so (z+\bar{z})=(7-5i)+(7+5i) = 14 and z\bar{z} \amp =(7-5i)(7+5i) \amp =49-25i^2 = 49+25=74
Let z=-3+4i. Compute (z+\bar{z}) and z\bar{z}.
Find a quadratic polynomial with one zero being z=-3+4i.

subsection.p: One of the most important results in mathematics is the fundamental theorem of algebra, which says that if we allow complex numbers as inputs, then every polynomial p(x) of degree n \ge 1 has exactly n complex number zeros.

assemblage.title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
assemblage.p: Let p(x) be a polynomial of degree n \ge 1. Then p(x) has exactly n complex zeros, counting multiplicities.

note.p: A polynomial has a zero "of multiplicity k" at x=a if (x-a) occurs k times as a factor of the polynomial. For example, the polynomial p(x) = (x-5)^2 has a zero of multiplicity 2 at x=5.

subsection.p: As a result, every polynomial of degree can be factored as the product of linear terms.

sidebyside.p: For example, although the graph of ~~y=x^4+4~~shown at right has no x-intercepts, the fundamental theorem tells us that there are four complex solutions to ~x^4+4=0~, and that x^4+4 can be factored. You can check that the four solutions to ~x^4+4=0~ are 1+i,~-1+i,~-1-i,~\text{and}~ 1-i

subsection.p:
For example, if x=1+i, then x^2=(1+i)^2=1+2i+i^2=2i and x^4=(x^2)^2=(2i)^2=-4
Because each zero corresponds to a factor of the polynomial, the factored form of x^4+4 is x^4+4=\left[x-(1+i)][x-(-1+i)\right]\left[x-(-1-i)\right]\left[x-(1-i)\right]
The four solutions to ~x^4+4=0~ form two complex conjugate pairs, namely 1 \pm i and -1 \pm i. We see again that, for every polynomial with real coefficients, the nonreal zeros always occur in complex conjugate pairs.

statement.p: Find a fourth degree polynomial with real coefficients, two of whose zeros are 3i and 2+i.

solution.p: The other two zeros are -3i and 2-i. The factored form of the polynomial is (x-3i)(x+3i)[x-(2+i)][x-(2-i)] We multiply together the factors to find the polynomial. The product of (x-3i)(x+3i) is x^2+9, and [x-(2+i)][x-(2-i)] \amp =x^2-(2+i+2-i)x+(2+i)(2-i) \amp = x^2-4x+5 Finally, we multiply these two partial products to find the polynomial we seek, (x^2+9)(x^2-4x+5)=x^4-4x^3+14x^2-36x+45

ol.li: Find the zeros of the polynomial x^4+15x^2-16.
Write the polynomial in factored form.
